SUBSECTION.NAME: Hierarchical Structures
SUBSECTION.TEXT:
The representation of sequences in terms of lists generalizes naturally to represent sequences whose elements may themselves be sequences. For example, we can regard the object ((1 2) 3 4)[[1,[2,[]]],[3,[4,[]]]] constructed by
(cons (list 1 2) (list 3 4))
pair(list(1,2),list(3,4))
as a list of three items, the first of which is itself a list, (1 2). Indeed, this is suggested by the form in which the result is printed by the interpreter.[1,[2,[]]]. Figure shows the representation of this structure in terms of pairs.
Structure formed by (cons (list 1 2) (list 3 4))pair(list(1,2),list(3,4)).

recursionworking@in working with trees Recursion is a natural tool for dealing with tree structures, since we can often reduce operations on trees to operations on their branches, which reduce in turn to operations on the branches of the branches, and so on, until we reach the leaves of the tree. To implement count-leavescount_leaves, recall the recursive plan for computing lengthlength:
LengthThe length of a list xx is 1 plus lengththe length of the cdrtail of xx.
LengthThe length of the empty list is 0.
Count-leavesThe function count_leaves is similar. The value for the empty list is the same:
Count-leavescount_leaves of the empty list is 0.
But in the reduction step, where we strip off the carhead of the list, we must take into account that the carhead may itself be a tree whose leaves we need to count. Thus, the appropriate reduction step is
Count-leavescount_leaves of a tree xx is count-leavescount_leaves of the carhead of xx plus count-leavescount_leaves of the cdrtail of xx.
Finally, by taking carheads we reach actual leaves, so we need another base case:
Count-leavescount_leaves of a leaf is 1.
To aid in writing recursive proceduresfunctions on trees, Schemeour JavaScript environment provides the primitive predicate
pair?is_pair, which tests whether its argument is a pair. Here is the complete procedurefunction:The order of the first two clauses in the cond matters, since the empty list satisfies null? and also is not a pair.
count_leaves count_leaves_example
(define (count-leaves x) (cond ((null? x) 0) ((not (pair? x)) 1) (else (+ (count-leaves (car x)) (count-leaves (cdr x))))))
function count_leaves(x) { if (is_empty_list(x)) return 0; else if (! is_pair(x)) return 1; else return count_leaves(head(x)) + count_leaves(tail(x)); }
count_leaves_example
(count-leaves (cons (list 1 2) (list 3 4)))
count_leaves([[1,[2,[]]],[3,[4,[]]]])

SUBSECTION.TEXT:
Just as mapmap is a powerful abstraction for dealing with sequences, mapmap together with recursion is a powerful abstraction for dealing with trees. For instance, the scale-treescale_tree procedurefunction, analogous to scale-listscale_list of Section, takes as arguments a numeric factor and a tree whose leaves are numbers. It returns a tree of the same shape, where each number is multiplied by the factor. The recursive plan for scale-treescale_tree is similar to the one for count-leavescount_leaves:
scale_tree scale_tree_example
(define (scale-tree tree factor) (cond ((null? tree) nil) ((not (pair? tree)) (* tree factor)) (else (cons (scale-tree (car tree) factor) (scale-tree (cdr tree) factor)))))
(10 (20 (30 40) 50) (60 70))
function scale_tree(tree,factor) { if (is_empty_list(tree)) return []; else if (! is_pair(tree)) return tree * factor; else return pair(scale_tree(head(tree),factor), scale_tree(tail(tree),factor)); }
scale_tree_example scale_tree
(scale-tree (list 1 (list 2 (list 3 4) 5) (list 6 7)) 10)
scale_tree(list(1,list(2,list(3,4),5),list(6,7)), 10)
Many tree operations can be implemented by similar combinations of sequence operations and recursion.
